facts.text: Appeals filed against judgment of Madras High Court dated 12.10.2009

anchor.surface_text: These appeals have been filed against the judgment of the Madras High Court dated 12.10.2009.

facts.text: Appellant alleged marriage to Lakshmi according to Hindu Customary Rites on 25.6.1980

anchor.surface_text: The appellant herein has alleged that he was married according to the Hindu Customary Rites with one Lakshmi on 25.6.1980.

facts.text: Male child born out of wedlock with Lakshmi, now studying in Engineering college at Ooty

anchor.surface_text: Out of the wedlock with Lakshmi a male child was born, who is number studying in an Engineering companylege at Ooty.

facts.text: Appellant working as Secondary Teacher in Thevanga Higher Secondary School, Coimbatore

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is working as a Secondary Teacher in Thevanga Higher Secondary School, Coimbatore.

facts.text: Respondent D. Patchaiammal filed petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. in 2001 before Family Court at Coimbatore

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the respondent-D. Patchaiammal filed a petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. in the year 2001 before the Family Court at Coimbatore

facts.text: Respondent alleged marriage to appellant on 14.9.1986

anchor.surface_text: in which she alleged that she was married to the appellant herein on 14.9.1986 and since then the appellant herein and she lived together

facts.text: Appellant and respondent lived together in her father's house for two or three years after 1986 marriage

anchor.surface_text: and since then the appellant herein and she lived together in her fathers house for two or three years.

facts.text: Appellant left respondent's father's house after two or three years and started living in native place, visiting occasionally

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged in the petition that after two or three years the appellant herein left the house of the respondents father and started living in his native place, but would visit the respondent occasionally.

facts.text: Respondent alleged deserted by appellant two or three years after 1986 marriage

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that the appellant herein  respondent in the petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C.  deserted the respondent herein  petitioner in the proceeding under Section 125 Cr.P.C.  two or three years after marrying her in 1986.

facts.text: Respondent alleged no livelihood, unable to maintain herself; appellant draws Rs.10000/- per month salary

anchor.surface_text: In her petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. she alleged that she did number have any kind of livelihood and she is unable to maintain herself whereas the respondent  appellant herein  is a Secondary Grade Teacher drawing a salary of Rs.10000/- per month.

facts.text: Respondent prayed for Rs.500/- per month maintenance from appellant

anchor.surface_text: Hence it was prayed that the respondent  appellant herein  be directed to pay Rs.500/- per month as maintenance to the petitioner.

facts.text: Respondent alleged in petition and deposition marriage on 14.9.1986 and appellant left after two or three years

anchor.surface_text: In both her petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. as well as in her deposition in the case the respondent has alleged that she was married to the appellant herein on 14.9.1986, and that he left her after two or three years of living together with her in her fathers house.

facts.text: Appellant left respondent in 1988 or 1989 per her own case

anchor.surface_text: Thus it is the own case of the respondent herein that the appellant left her in 1988 or 1989  i.e. two or three years after the alleged marriage in 1986 .

facts.text: Section 125 Cr.P.C. petition filed by respondent in 2001, after 12 years delay from 1988/89

anchor.surface_text: Why then was the petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. filed in the year 2001, i.e. after a delay of about twelve years, shall have to be satisfactorily explained by the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant filed counter affidavit before Family Court alleging marriage to Lakshmi on 25.6.1980 and male child studying in C.S.I. Engineering college at Ooty

anchor.surface_text: In his companynter affidavit filed by the appellant herein before the Family Court, Coimbatore, it was alleged that the respondent  appellant herein  was married to one Lakshmi on 25.6.1980 as per the Hindu Marriage rites and customs and he had a male child, who is studying in C.S.I. Engineering companylege at Ooty.

facts.text: Appellant produced ration card, voters identity card of wife, transfer certificate of son, discharge certificate of wife from hospital, wedding photographs to prove marriage to Lakshmi

anchor.surface_text: To prove his marriage with Lakshmi the appellant produced the ration card, voters identity card of his wife, transfer certificate of his son, discharge certificate of his wife Lakshmi from hospital, photographs of the wedding, etc.

facts.text: Family Court Judge held by judgment dated 5.3.2004 that appellant was married to respondent and not to Lakshmi

anchor.surface_text: The learned Family Court Judge has held by his judgment dated 5.3.2004 that the appellant was married to the respondent and number to Lakshmi.

facts.text: Madras High Court upheld Family Court findings by impugned judgment

anchor.surface_text: These findings have been upheld by the High Court in the impugned judgment.

facts.text: Lakshmi was not made a party to proceedings before Family Court or High Court, no notice issued to her

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, since Lakshmi was number made a party to the proceedings before the Family Court Judge or before the High Court and numbernotice was issued to her hence any declaration about her marital status vis-- vis the appellant is wholly null and void

facts.text: Supreme Court holds lower courts' finding that Lakshmi not married to appellant is null and void, violative of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: as it will be violative of the rules of natural justice. Without giving a hearing to Lakshmi numbersuch declaration companyld have validly be given by the Courts below that she had number married the appellant herein since such as a finding would seriously affect her rights.

facts.text: Leave granted in appeals

anchor.surface_text: Markandey Katju, J. Leave granted.

facts.text: Heard learned counsel for appellant; none appeared for respondent though served notice

anchor.surface_text: Heard learned companynsel for the appellant. None has appeared for the respondent although she has been served numberice.

facts.text: Mr. Jayant Bhushan appointed and assisted as Amicus Curiae

anchor.surface_text: We had earlier requested Mr. Jayant Bhushan, learned Senior companynsel to assist us as Amicus Curiae in the case, and we record our appreciation of Mr. Bhushan who was of companysiderable assistance to us.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2(a) of the Act states (2)(a) aggrieved person means any woman who is, or has been, in a domestic relationship with the respondent
Section 2(f) states (2)(f) domestic relationship means a relationship between two persons who live or have, at any point of time, lived together in a shared household

concepts.unlisted_description: Definition of domestic relationship including relationship in the nature of marriage

anchor.surface_text: Section 2(s) states (2)(s) shared household means a household where the person aggrieved lives or at any stage has lived in a domestic relationship
Section 3(a) states that an act will constitute domestic violence in case it- (3)(a) harms or injures or endangers the health, safety, life, limb or well-being

concepts.unlisted_description: Acts constituting domestic violence including economic abuse

anchor.surface_text: The expression economic abuse has been defined to include (a) deprivation of all or any economic or financial resources to which the aggrieved person is entitled under any law or custom

concepts.unlisted_description: Includes deprivation of financial resources, maintenance etc.

anchor.surface_text: An aggrieved person under the Act can approach the Magistrate under Section 12 for the relief mentioned in Section 12(2).
Under Section 20(1)(d) the Magistrate can grant maintenance while disposing of the application under Section 12(1).
Section 26(1) provides that the relief mentioned in Section 20 may also be sought in any legal proceeding, before a civil court, family court or a criminal court.
the expression domestic relationship includes not only the relationship of marriage but also a relationship in the nature of marriage.

issues.text: Whether any declaration about Lakshmi's marital status vis-a-vis the appellant is valid without making her a party to the proceedings or issuing notice to her

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, since Lakshmi was not made a party to the proceedings before the Family Court Judge or before the High Court and no notice was issued to her hence any declaration about her marital status vis-a-vis the appellant is wholly null and void as it will be violative of the rules of natural justice. Without giving a hearing to Lakshmi no such declaration could have validly be given by the Courts below that she had not married the appellant herein since such a finding would seriously affect her rights.

issues.text: Whether the respondent is the legally wedded wife of the appellant entitled to maintenance under Section 125 Cr.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the respondent-D. Patchaiammal filed a petition under Section 125 Cr.P.C. in the year 2001 before the Family Court at Coimbatore in which she alleged that she was married to the appellant herein on 14.9.1986 and since then the appellant herein and she lived together in her fathers house for two or three years. ... However, under the law a second wife whose marriage is void on account of the survival of the first marriage is not a legally wedded wife, and is, therefore, not entitled to maintenance under this provision.

issues.text: What is the meaning of the expression 'a relationship in the nature of marriage' under the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005

anchor.surface_text: the expression domestic relationship includes not only the relationship of marriage but also a relationship in the nature of marriage. The question, therefore, arises as to what is the meaning of the expression a relationship in the nature of marriage. Unfortunately this expression has not been defined in the Act. Since there is no direct decision of this Court on the interpretation of this expression we think it necessary to interpret it
